entry.title: HANA ML Data Drift Detector
entry.content:
The release of HANA ML 2.23 includes a new function called: APL data drift detector. This drift detector helps you spot changes or deviations between a given dataset and a reference. Reference data could be a version in the past, or a particular segment of customers or employees, or an expected distribution (e.g. Benford). Use cases of data comparison are:

  • This year employee survey results versus last year results by country
  • Machine learning inference dataset versus training dataset
  • Male staff versus female staff
  • Payment amounts by legal entity versus the Benford‚Äôs law to find potential fraud

This feature from APL (Automated Predictive Library) is available for both Python and SQL.

The rest of this blog will walk you through a scenario with code snippets in Python as well as SQL that you can reuse and adapt to your own case.

We chose to work with Olympics athletes and results data. The dataset contains summer and winter games since 1896. We want to make a comparison over time.

First, we connect to the SAP HANA database using a Python notebook.

DB_Host='host'  
DB_Port='port_number'
DB_User='user_name'
DB_Password='user_password'

from hana_ml import dataframe as hd
conn = hd.ConnectionContext(address = DB_Host, port = DB_Port, 
                            user = DB_User, password = DB_Password, 
                            encrypt = 'true', sslValidateCertificate = 'false' )
conn.connection.isconnected()

The reference dataframe comprises the Olympic games before 1970 ‚Ä¶

sql_cmd =  """ 
select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport" 
from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
where "Year" <= 1970  
order by "Id"
"""
hdf_ref= hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd)
hdf_ref.head(5).collect()

 

 

 

 

‚Ä¶ and the comparison dataframe, after 1970:

sql_cmd =  """ 
select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport"
from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
where "Year" > 1970 
order by "Id"
"""
hdf_new= hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd)
hdf_new.head(5).collect()

 

 

 

 

The code to run the comparison is the following:

from hana_ml.algorithms.apl.drift_detector import DriftDetector
apl_model = DriftDetector()
results = apl_model.fit_detect(hdf_ref, hdf_new, build_report=True)
print(results.collect())

 

 

 

All the variables appearing here have a deviation indicator over 0.95. This threshold can be changed with the syntax below:

results = apl_model.fit_detect(hdf_ref, hdf_new, threshold=0.80)

Here is a report putting the two datasets side by side with their counts (aka weight) by category; the most changing categories (top 10 here) appear first:

df = apl_model.get_debrief_report('Deviation_CategoryFrequencies').head(10).deselect(['Oid','Category Order']).collect()
format_dict = {
    'Ref Weight': '{:,.0f}', 'New Weight': '{:,.0f}', 'Change': '{:,.0f}', 
    'Ref % Weight': '{:.1f}', 'New % Weight': '{:.1f}', '% Change': '{:.1f}', 'Abs % Change': '{:.1f}'
}
df.style.format(format_dict).hide(axis='index')

KxMissing is a special category created by APL when finding empty or null values. With far less missing values on athletes‚Äô height and weight, we see that data quality is getting better overtime.

More women are participating to the Olympic games after 1970. The male % change value mirrors the female % change value. The same remark applies to summer and winter seasons.

The following code brings the data drift results as charts:

apl_model.generate_notebook_iframe_report()
# apl_model.generate_html_report('drift_olympics')

After comparing athletes across all types of sports, let‚Äôs compare them by sport. For that we must provide the drift detector with two dataframes sorted by Sport:

## Reference Dataset
sql_cmd =  """ 
select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport" 
from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
where "Year" <= 1970  
order by "Sport", "Id"
"""
hdf_ref= hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd)
hdf_ref.head(5).collect()

 

 

 

 

## Dataset for comparison
sql_cmd =  """ 
select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport" 
from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
where "Year" > 1970  
order by "Sport", "Id"
"""
hdf_new= hd.DataFrame(conn, sql_cmd)
hdf_new.head(5).collect()

 

 

 

 

You specify the segment for drift detection the same way as for segmented forecasting, regression or classification scenarios:

col_segment= 'Sport'    
from hana_ml.algorithms.apl.drift_detector import DriftDetector
apl_model = DriftDetector(segment_column_name= col_segment, max_tasks= 4)
results = apl_model.fit_detect(hdf_ref, hdf_new, threshold=0.95)
print(results.sort(["Segment","Variable"]).collect())

The deviating variables appear for each sport:

 

 

 

 

 

We check if there are segments with status ‚ÄòFailed‚Äô:

my_filter = "KEY in ('AplTaskStatus') and VALUE ='Failed'"
df = apl_model.get_summary().filter(my_filter).select('OID').collect()
failed_segments = df['OID'].tolist()
print('Preview of failed segments')
print(failed_segments[:5])

 

The log contains the cause of failure:

df = apl_model.get_fit_operation_log().filter("LEVEL = 0").select('OID','ORIGIN','MESSAGE').head(5).collect()
df.columns = [col_segment, 'Cause', 'Error']
df.style.hide(axis='index')

 

 

 

These sports were introduced after 1970. Thus, there is no reference data to compare against.

To obtain the Data Drift report, you must provide a segment value as in the example below:

seg_value = "Swimming"
apl_model.build_report(segment_name=seg_value)
apl_model.generate_notebook_iframe_report()
#apl_model.generate_html_report('Sport_Report')

 

We are nearing the end of this post, and you have not yet seen how to run a comparison with the SQL interface. Here is the syntax for calling the new APL function COMPARE_DATA from a SQL script:

drop view DATASET_1;
create view DATASET_1 as (
 select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport"
 from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
 where "Year" <= 1970  
 order by "Sport", "Id"
);

drop view DATASET_2;
create view DATASET_2 as (
 select "Height", "Weight", "Age", "Medal", "Gender", "Season", "Country", "Sport"
 from "APL_SAMPLES"."OLYMPICS" 
 where "Year" > 1970  
 order by "Sport", "Id"
);

DO BEGIN
    declare header "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.FUNCTION_HEADER";
    declare config "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_CONFIG_EXTENDED";   
    declare var_desc "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_DESC_OID";      
    declare var_role "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_ROLES_WITH_COMPOSITES_OID";      
    declare out_log   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";             
    declare out_summary  "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";   
    declare out_metric   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";      
    declare out_property "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";
 
    :header.insert(('Oid', 'Before-After 1970'));

    :config.insert(('APL/SegmentColumnName', 'Sport',null)); 

	:var_desc.insert((0,'Height','number','continuous',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	:var_desc.insert((1,'Weight','number','continuous',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	:var_desc.insert((2,'Age','integer','continuous',0,0,null,null,null,null));
    :var_desc.insert((3,'Medal','string','nominal',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	:var_desc.insert((4,'Gender','string','nominal',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	:var_desc.insert((5,'Season','string','nominal',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	:var_desc.insert((6,'Country','string','nominal',0,0,null,null,null,null));
	
	"SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::COMPARE_DATA" (
	:header, :config, :var_desc, :var_role,'USER_APL','DATASET_1', 'USER_APL','DATASET_2', 
	out_log, out_summary, out_metric, out_property );
 
 	select value as "Status", count(*) as "Nb of Segments" from :out_summary where key = 'AplTaskStatus' group by value;
	select OID as "Sport", message as "Error" from :out_log where level=0;
	 	
    select * from SAP_PA_APL."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::Deviation_ByVariable"(:out_property,:out_metric, Deviation_Threshold => 0.9);
    select * from SAP_PA_APL."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::Deviation_ByCategory"(:out_property,:out_metric, Deviation_Threshold => 0.9); 
    select * from SAP_PA_APL."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::Deviation_CategoryFrequencies"(:out_property,:out_metric) order by "Abs % Change" desc;
END;

-- Cases where a comparison is not possible
select "Sport" from "DATASET_1" minus select "Sport" from "DATASET_2"; -- Sports that have been removed 
select "Sport" from "DATASET_2" minus select "Sport" from "DATASET_1"; -- New Sports

 

The APL drift detector supports also a 2-step approach to address the cases where you have a changing dataset that needs to be compared on a regular basis (e.g. every week or every month) to a fixed reference. The samples below illustrate how it works with Python:

Data Drift Step 1 notebook   Data Drift Step 2 notebook 

and with SQL:

Data Drift Step 1 script   Data Drift Step 2 script 

 

Happy data drift detection with APL.

To know more about APL

entry.title: Data Lineage ‚Äì Do it Yourself with SAP HANA and SAC
entry.content:
Management Summary 

  1. Data lineage is crucial for understanding the origin and usage of data ‚Äì a central requirement for data governance, data quality, and efficient data management. 
  2. With SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a cost-effective and quickly implementable solution for data lineage can be realized, as both products are already included in the licensing of many companies. 
  3. The Object Dependencies in SAP HANA provide comprehensive information about dependencies between tables, views, and other objects, which can be directly read in SAC via a live connection. 
  4. Thanks to the R-integration in SAC (e.g., with the R package "collapsibleTree"), an interactive tree representation is created, offering business users an intuitive and transparent overview of data flows and relationships. 
  5. This approach enables an automated, real-time view of data origin, improves the maintainability of reports and data models, and lays the foundation for reliable and data governance-compliant analytics applications.

Introduction

In modern data warehouse architectures, data lineage plays an increasingly important role. Companies want to trace where data comes from, how it is transformed, and in which reports it is ultimately used. Transparent data origin significantly contributes to data quality and governance. It also creates data understanding and facilitates the implementation of reporting requirements, especially in self-service environments.

Companies with an SAP tech stack are often familiar with the principle of data lineage from SAP BW, where data flows can be visualized via the data flow object. However, in modern system landscapes where SAP BW is combined with SAP HANA ‚Äì for example, through hybrid architectures with native HANA views and BW objects ‚Äì this visualization reaches its limits. In native HANA development, such visualization options are even completely missing.

Although established tools like Collibra or D-QUANTUM offer comprehensive lineage functions, they require additional licenses, implementation effort and a structuring of organizational process to get the full potential out of the tools. For many use cases ‚Äì such as error analysis or the development of new requirements ‚Äì a lighter solution is sufficient.

Therefore, we looked for a lean and quickly implementable alternative that supports development in complex system landscapes. Our goal: to automatically identify and visualize the dependencies of SAP HANA objects ‚Äì without additional third-party tools.

In this blog post, we show how to implement a cost-effective and quick visualization of data lineage using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and a live connection to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). A special highlight: Through the integration of R in SAC (including the R package "collapsibleTree"), data origin is visualized in an interactive tree structure in an SAC story.

 

Motivation: Why Data Lineage?

The requirements for transparency, traceability, and efficiency in data architectures are increasing ‚Äì especially in regulated and data-driven companies. Data lineage makes a decisive contribution here:

  • Transparency: Knowing the origin and usage of data creates trust and better decision-making foundations.
  • Data understanding: A clear overview of data flows facilitates both operation and the implementation of reporting and analysis requirements.
  • Maintainability: Changes in the data model can be better assessed if the affected downstream objects are known.
  • Compliance: Regulations like GDPR require traceable documentation of data processing.

Many companies already have some form of data lineage ‚Äì but usually maintained manually by data engineers in PowerPoint, Excel, or Word. The result: high maintenance effort, outdated documentation, and lack of up-to-date information in ongoing operations.

Our solution is based on existing SAP HANA and SAC licenses and combines automated determination of data flows with an interactive representation through R integration. This creates a maintainable, always up-to-date, and interactive overview of data flows ‚Äì without additional tools or costs.

 

Technical Background: SAP HANA Object Dependencies

SAP HANA provides Object Dependencies in the form of metadata tables and views, where relationships between different objects are stored. Here you can find information about which objects depend on and are linked to each other. A brief overview:

  • Data source: The Objects Dependencies View can be found in the HANA schema SYS under the name OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.
  • Object types: Tables, views, stored procedures, etc.
  • Dependencies: Relationships between objects, e.g., which tables or views are used for an SAC report.
  • Usage: Supports impact and lineage analyses directly at the database level.

Through a live connection in SAP Analytics Cloud, this information can be queried and visualized in real-time.

Figure 1: Extract from the Object Dependencies | SELECT TOP 1000 * FROM SYS.OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.

Implementation in SAP Analytics Cloud

To implement the data lineage solution in SAC, two prerequisites must be met:

  • Live connection to SAP HANA: With the HANA live connection the necessary metadata is read from HANA in real time to ensure that it is up to date. This live connection must be created.
  • R server configuration: An R package is used for visualization. The use of R must be activated in SAC.

The necessary steps in order to create the lineage visualization can be summarized as follows:

  • Data preparation in SAP HANA
    • Preparation of metadata: For optimal visualization, the metadata is prepared, e.g., filtering object types, enriching descriptions.
    • Provision as a calculation view: The data is prepared as a calculation view as a basis for the SAC story.
  • Establishing a live connection to HANA
    • Configure live connection: Set up the HANA connection in SAC under Connections ‚Üí Live Data Connection.
    • Create data model in SAC: Reference the live data model to the created view/table.
  • Activate R integration in SAC
    • Configure R server: Specify the R server in SAC administration under System Configuration (either own server or the environment provided by SAP).
    • Create R scripts: In a story or an analytic application, the R package "collapsibleTree" can be loaded using the R widget function.
  • Create data lineage visualization with "collapsibleTree"
    • Pass data to R: Load the HANA table or view data into an R-compatible table structure via the R script in SAC.
    • Generate tree structure: Create an interactive tree representation with collapsibleTree::collapsibleTree(...) or a similar function.
    • Embed result: The generated graphic appears directly in the SAC story within the R widget and can be filtered and extended as needed.

Results and Benefits

  • Quick & cost-effective implementation: In this case, the customer already had SAP HANA and SAC licensed, so no additional investments were necessary.
  • Automation: Dependencies are read directly from SAP HANA Object Dependencies, eliminating the need for a separate ETL process or manual maintenance.
  • Interactive representation: Users can click through the tree structure and trace relationships between objects.

Figure 2: Representation of the data lineage within a SAC story.

Best Practices & Tips

  • Performance: For very large data volumes, it is advisable to perform aggregation or filtering in HANA beforehand and persist it.
  • Naming conventions: Consistent naming for tables and views makes the tree diagram easier to read.
  • Limitations: Complex procedures or dynamic SQL are not always fully recognized ‚Äì additional manual mapping may be necessary.
  • Visualization in R: For data lineage representation, we use the R package collapsibleTree, which is included in the SAP-provided R runtime environment (packages in the SAP R server environment). It can be used directly and free of charge in SAC without additional infrastructure. For extended visualization options, an own R server with additional packages can alternatively be connected.

 

Conclusion and Outlook

The visualization of data lineage in SAP Analytics Cloud using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and the R package "collapsibleTree" is a lean and cost-effective solution for companies that want to make their data origin traceable.

Thanks to the live data connection between HANA and SAC, no complicated interfaces or additional licenses are needed. With the out-of-the-box R integration and the interactive widgets of SAC, the origin and usage of tables can be traced in detail with just a few clicks.

The presented solution offers an efficient way, minimum in the short term, to provide developers and business units with more transparency about data flows. In the medium to long term, the use of specialized data governance solutions like Collibra or D-Quantum is recommended to centrally manage lineage, documentation, and responsibilities.

 

Questions, Feedback, and Contact

We are happy to answer questions and engage in further discussions ‚Äì either in the comments or through direct contact.

Do you need more information?

  • If further technical information is desired (e.g., configuration of the R server, scripting in SAC, performance optimization, manual mapping), let us know!
  • We are happy to dive deeper into the implementation details in a personal conversation.

We look forward to the exchange and are happy to provide further advice and implementation in the area of SAP Data & Analytics.

entry.title: Developing a Shell Plugin for SAP Build Work Zone to Display Custom Notifications on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction‚ÄÉ

Unlocking Custom Experiences in SAP Build Work Zone: Shell Plugin in Action
In today‚Äôs digital workplace, personalization is key. This article showcases how to enhance SAP Build Work Zone with a custom shell plugin that brings tailored notifications right to the user‚Äôs fingertips. Using a Multi-Target UI5/CAP application, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to create, manage, and surface custom alerts‚Äîseamlessly integrated into your Work Zone experience.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To replicate this you should have a base knowledge of SAP BTP, JS, SAPUI5 and SAP CAP, I will not go deep down in to how to generate a project in BAS, or create an instance in SAP BTP. 

***GITHUB URL REMOVED BY MODERATION***

Project Architecture

‚ÄÉ

Backend/Frontend App Development:

Generate a regular SAP CAP application

Firstly I've created a primitave data structure under db/schema.cds

namespace my.Notification;

entity Notification {
    key ID : UUID;
    type: String(30);
    title: String;
    message: String;
}

 Than a service at srv/service.cds:

using { my.Notification as my } from '../db/schema';

service NotificationService {
    entity Notification as projection on my.Notification;
}

And the backend is almost done, now add an app router and a sapui5 freestyle base app to the project.

Now let's add a form to create and delete the notifications under app/<app name>/webapp/view/<view name>.view.xml:

 

Spoiler
Remember to correct the controller name if you copy the code

 

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:form="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">

    <Toolbar>
        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
    </Toolbar>

    <Shell id="mainShell">
        <VBox class="sapUiSmallMargin">
            <form:SimpleForm
                    editable="true"
                    layout="ResponsiveGridLayout"
                    labelSpanL="1" labelSpanM="2"
                    adjustLabelSpan="false"
                    columnsL="3" columnsM="3"
                    class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">

                    <Label text="Type" />
                    <ComboBox id="newType" selectedKey="information">
                        <core:Item key="Warning" text="Warning" />
                        <core:Item key="Success" text="Success" />
                        <core:Item key="Information" text="Information" />
                        <core:Item key="Error" text="Error" />
                        <core:Item key="Alert" text="Alert" />
                        <core:Item key="Confirm" text="Confirm" />
                    </ComboBox>

                    <Label text="Title" />
                    <Input id="newTitle" />

                    <Label text="Message" />
                    <Input id="newMessage" />

                    <Label text="" />
                    <Button text="Add Notification"
                        press="onAddNotification"
                        type="Emphasized"/>
                </form:SimpleForm>

            <!-- Table Section -->
            <Table id="shellNotificationsTable" items="{/Notification}">
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Delete" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Type" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Title" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Message" />
                    </Column>
                </columns>

                <items>
                    <ColumnListItem>
                        <cells>
                            <Button icon="sap-icon://delete" type="Negative" press="deleteRow" />
                            <Text text="{type}" />
                            <Text text="{title}" />
                            <Text text="{message}" />
                        </cells>
                    </ColumnListItem>
                </items>
            </Table>
        </VBox>
    </Shell>
</mvc:View>

As next let's implement the controller that manages the view with all the necessary notification creation/deletion methods:

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/m/MessageBox",
	"sap/m/MessageToast"
], (Controller, MessageBox, MessageToast) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView", {
        onInit() {

        },

        deleteRow: function (oEvent) {
			var oContext = oEvent.getSource().getBindingContext().getObject();
			console.log(oContext);
			MessageBox.confirm("Are your sure you want to delete this message?", {
				title: "Confirm",
				onClose: function (sAction) {
					if (sAction === "OK") {
						this.onDeleteSpecificRecord(oContext)
					}
				}.bind(this),
				actions: [
					MessageBox.Action.OK,
					MessageBox.Action.CANCEL
				],
				emphasizedAction: MessageBox.Action.OK
			})
		},

		onDeleteSpecificRecord: function (oRecord) {
			var oDataModel = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel();
			var oBusyDialog = new sap.m.BusyDialog({
				title: "Deleting Record",
				text: "Please Wait ..."
			})
			oBusyDialog.open();
			oDataModel.delete(`/Notification('${oRecord.ID}')`)
				.then(() => {
					console.log("Record deleted successfully");
				})
				.catch((error) => {
					console.error("Deletion failed:", error);
				})
				.finally(() => {
					this.getView().byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").refresh();
					oBusyDialog.close();
				});
		},

		onAddNotification: function () {
			const sType = this.byId("newType").getValue();
			const sTitle = this.byId("newTitle").getValue();
			const sMessage = this.byId("newMessage").getValue();

			this.byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").create({
				"type": sType,
				"title": sTitle,
				"message": sMessage
			}).created().then(function() {
				MessageToast.show("Created")
			})
		}
    });
});

The last thing to do is to add all the features that you need to the application, like HANA DB, xsuaa in my case, to do so just run

cds add hana
cds add xsuaa

And like this is the app ready, let's deploy it, firstly login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

then right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"

then go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

BTP Steps

To connect to the app from the shell plugin you need to create a SAP BTP Destination, 

to do so go to <BTP Subaccount> -> Cloud Foundry -> <Your space> -> <Your app name>-srv and copy it's address, that's your destination URL

Now you need to get the authentication data for the Destination

Go to <Your CF Space> -> Instances -> <Your app name>-auth -> <Your app name>-auth-key 

Copy these:

Client ID, Client secret and url (Access Token URL)

Now go back to your Subaccount and create a new destination with your data:

  • URL:  app-srv URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • ClientID: ClientID
  • Client secret: Client secret
  • Token service URL type: Dedicated
  • Token Service URL: <Access token URL>/oauth/token

After this add these 2 parameters:

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
  • WebIDEEnabled: true

With this step is the backend development concluded.

Shell Plugin Development:

Firstly a general explanation about shell plugins. Shell Plugins are UI5 Applications that allow to add new Elements to SAP Build Work Zone/Fiori Launchpad like Headers, Footers, menu items etc.

To create a shell plugin generate a plain UI5 Basic Freestyle application with the "Template Wizard" in Business Application Studio.

There are a couple of things to modify in the manifest.json to make a a Shell Plugin:

Inside sap.app change the type to component:

"type": "component"

In sap.app>crossNavigation hide the launcher:

"crossNavigation": {
      "inbounds": {
        "Shell-plugin": {
          "semanticObject": "Shell",
          "action": "plugin",
          "title": "{{Shell-plugin.flpTitle}}",
          "hideLauncher": true,
          "icon": "",
          "signature": {
            "parameters": {},
            "additionalParameters": "allowed"
          }
        }
      }
    },

 Add this part under after sap.cloud:

"sap.flp": {
    "type": "plugin"
  }

  This way the Shell Plugin configuration is completed, now let's add our newly created Destination

in sap.app>dataSources add this:

"NotificationService": {
        "uri": "/ShellNotifications/odata/v4/notification/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }

and in sap.ui5>models: 

"Notification": {
        "dataSource": "NotificationService",
        "settings": {
          "synchronizationMode": "None",  
          "operationMode": "Server",
          "autoExpandSelect": true
        },
        "type": "sap.ui.model.odata.v4.ODataModel"
      }

and as last thing add this route to your xs-app.json file:

 

Spoiler
Remember: the order of the routes in xs-app matters, if you add it at the end it might not be resolved correctly by the app router

 

{
      "source": "^/ShellNotifications/(.*)$",
      "destination": "ShellNotifications",
      "target": "$1",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
      "csrfProtection": true
    },

Now finally you can add the code that displays the notifications, to do so open the Component.js file and add the following code to the init method:

const oModel = this.getModel("Notification");

            oModel.bindList("/Notification").requestContexts().then((aContexts) => {
                const aData = aContexts.map(oContext => oContext.getObject());
                for (const el of aData) {
                    const nType = el["type"];
                    const nTitle = el["title"];
                    const nMessage = el["message"]
                    if (nType === "Information") {
                        MessageBox.information(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        });
                    } else if (nType === "Alert") {
                        MessageBox.alert(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Confirm") {
                        MessageBox.confirm(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Error") {
                        MessageBox.error(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Success") {
                        MessageBox.success(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Warning") {
                        MessageBox.warning(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    }
                }
            }).catch((err) => {
                console.error("Failed to load notifications:", err);
            });

 And like this is the development finished, the last step is to deploy it and add to WorkZone.

To build it do the same steps as with the MTA app:

  • right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"
  • go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

SAP Build Work Zone Steps

Although the SAP Build Work Zone standard and advanced edition have some UI differences, the steps are the same for both of them.

All the steps performed below are done on SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition.

Start by going to the Administration Console -> External Integration -> Business Content -> Content Manager

‚ÄÉThan open the content channel and update the "HTML5 Apps"

‚ÄÉAfter that go Content Explorer and click Content Explorer (In the current UI it's a button in the header)

Select "HTML5 Apps" and add the new Shell Plugin that you just created

‚ÄÉTo be able to see the plugin, assign it to a role, in my case it's the "Everyone" role, you can find it in the Content Manager

‚ÄÉAfter you've done that you should be able to see your new shell plugin the SAP Build Work Zone's launchpad

‚ÄÉIf you don't see it try to open the page in an "Anonymous" Tab and check the developer console

Conclusion

What we‚Äôve built here is just a glimpse into what‚Äôs possible with shell plugins in SAP Build Work Zone. By integrating a custom notification system, we‚Äôve shown how easily you can extend the platform to better fit your customers‚Äô needs. But this is only the starting point.

There‚Äôs a wide range of enhancements you can explore next‚Äîsuch as targeting specific users with personalized notifications, adding actionable buttons to each alert, or even integrating with external systems to trigger real-time messages. The flexibility of shell extensions offers endless opportunities to enrich the Work Zone experience and tailor it to your organization‚Äôs workflows.

So go ahead‚Äîexperiment, extend, and elevate your Work Zone.

entry.title: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
I am writing this blog for publishing on the SAP Community, focused on SAP HANA Performance Optimization. It's structured to be informative, experience-driven, and valuable to a technical audience.

SAP HANA is known for its lightning-fast in-memory computing power, but like any high-performance engine, it requires Parameters tuning, Maintenance, and optimization to ensure it's running at its peak. Whether you're an SAP Basis Consultant, HANA Admin, or someone involved in performance analysis, this guide will walk you through proven techniques and practical tips that have worked in real-world SAP projects. HANA Parameters Tuning required in case of Migration, Implementation Projects as well as Support AMS Project.

When we are migrated to SAP HANA or Installing New Hana Database, all parameters are default parameters which may not perform as per your requirement or as per your landscape So we need to tune those parameters for system performance. SAP HANA parameter tuning for performance optimization involves configuring various system settings to maximize efficiency. Key areas include data modeling, load optimization, query optimization, and utilizing features like partitioning and columnar storage. Fine-tuning these parameters can significantly impact data processing speed, memory usage, and overall system responsiveness

Why HANA Performance Optimization Matters ?

In an enterprise environment, poor performance can impact business processes, reporting speed, and even downstream applications. Optimizing HANA ensures:

  • Faster analytics and reporting
  • Better end-user experience
  • Reduced infrastructure costs
  • Longer hardware lifecycle

 SAP S/4HANA End-to-End Performance Overview

SAP S/4HANA Architecture consist of 3-tiers, a SAP Fiori UI5 frontend, an SAP S/4HANA ABAP backend and a SAP HANA database

Database and ABAP processing times are two primary components of ABAP response time. Effects of pushing code to SAP HANA changes standard metrics of ABAP and database time as well as the common SAP R/3  and S/4 standard of 1 second per Dialog step.

Some SAP HANA features and ABAP coding that contribute to backend response times.

  • Core Data Services (CDS)
  • ABAP Managed Database Procedures
  • Compatibility views
  • Parallel processing in SAP HANA
  • Columnar in-memory database

End-to-End performance of an SAP S/4HANA system is spread across 4 layers: SAP Fiori UI, SAP S/4HANA  ABAP layer, CDS views and SAP HANA

Below are 11 Points need to perform for HANA Performance Optimization.

1. Monitor Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

Start with regular monitoring of essential KPIs:

Spikes during peak load

Long-running or unoptimized SQLs

Delta Merge Status

High frequency or failing merges

2. Use the HANA Cockpit and HANA Studio Wisely

Both tools provide dashboards to analyze:

  • Memory load and footprint
  • Active sessions and threads
  • Expensive SQL statements
  • Alerts (CPU, Disk, Memory, column unloads)

Tip: Configure alerting thresholds to get notified before performance degrades.

3. Data Volume Management (DVM)

Large tables or outdated data can slow down performance.

  • Archive or purge old data
  • Split large tables into partitions
  • Use RSDA_DATA_SELECT or DBACOCKPIT to find large table

5. Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA.

Run the HANA_Configuration_Parameters_1.00.90+ or HANA_Configuration_Parameters_2.00.040+.txt script, which is maintained in SAP note 1969700 SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA (below is a sample output) , Do Mini Checks in System and check all parameters and set SAP recommended parameters accordingly.

Additional Info

  • These checks can be executed on the SYSTEMDB and on each Tenant DB (for Hana 2.0) - but are particularly important for the Tenant DB's
  • Each Tenant DB can have different parameter values set, depending on each customer requirement
  • It is recommended that each Tenant has these best practice parameter values in place before productive use starts i.e. run these checks immediately after installation or upgrade, implement parameter value recommendations and test that these meet your business requirements
  • The output of the script will only show Hana parameters which are not currently set as per best practice recommendations
  • It will give recommended parameter value settings and note references on the particular parameter/topic area
  • In the P (Priority) column, you can see the most critical parameters to be set - 1 has highest priority
  • It will give actual SQL commands (ALTER statements) to set the parameter to the required value
  • And also an UNDO_COMMAND should you need to revert the parameter
  • If opening a support case with SAP Technical Support, providing the output of this parameter check will help to speed up the analysis
  • Check out the SAP HANA Configuration Parameter Reference: Index guide as per your HANA revision
  • In List SAP also provides Commands to modify Parameters. Just need to run those commands at SQL in HANA Cockpit or Studio.

6. List of Parameters Tuning at Linux OS Level.

7. OS and Infrastructure Checks

  • Ensure proper NUMA configuration
  • Keep kernel and firmware updated
  • Use SSDs for /hana/data and /hana/log
  • Monitor swap usage: HANA hates swapping!

 9. Smart Delta Merge Strategy

Delta merges can cause spikes in memory and CPU.

  • Check M_DELTA_MERGE_STATISTICS regularly
  • Avoid frequent merges on volatile tables
  • Automate delta merge scheduling for off-peak times

Tip: Always back up config and consult SAP notes before changing parameters.

To keep control of the delta merge we keep our table enable AUTOMERGE but in the data loading time we keep it into disable auto merge and enable smart merge for large volume tables.

Auto Merge :  HANA keeps a compressed ‚Äúmain‚Äù store of column tables and an uncompressed ‚Äúdelta‚Äù store, for new items. Periodically, a process called mergedog combines the two in a DELTA MERGE process. Sometimes however your tables may not be configured to automerge (you can issue ALTER TABLE table name ENABLE AUTOMERGE), and occasionally merged fails and you have to restart HANA. This can cause the delta store to become very large, and because it is uncompressed, this is a big issue if you don‚Äôt have much RAM.

Below Command:-

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ALTER TABLE ‚ÄúSCHEMA‚Äù.‚ÄùTABLE‚Äù DISABLE AUTOMERGE;

IMPORT FROM ‚Äò/sapmnt/log/test.ctl‚Äô WITH THREADS 120 BATCH 200000;

MERGE DELTA OF ‚ÄúSCHEMA‚Äù.‚ÄùTABLE‚Äù;

ALTER TABLE ‚ÄúSCHEMA‚Äù.‚ÄùTABLE ENABLE AUTOMERGE;

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

10. Use SAP Recommendations & Notes.

SAP regularly publishes SAP HANA performance-related notes. Some helpful ones include:

  • SAP Note 1999997 ‚Äì SAP HANA Troubleshooting Guide (FAQ: SAP HANA Memory)
  • SAP Note 2399079 ‚Äì Elimination of hdbparam in HANA 2
  • SAP Note 2186744 FAQ: SAP HANA Parameters.
  • SAP Note 2600030 Parameter Recommendations in SAP HANA Environments

 11. Periodic Housekeeping

  • Clean up old logs and trace files.
  • Reclaim memory, data volume and logs (ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOGS, MEMORY, DATAVOLUME)
  • Remove obsolete backups from disk

SAP HANA is a powerful platform, but like any high-performance machine, it needs care and attention. By combining smart monitoring, regular analysis, and data management best practices, you can keep your system running efficiently and support your business-critical operations smoothly.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Beginners: Everything You Need to Know - All at one stop!
entry.content:
This blog is for anyone in the SAP domain ‚Äî from consultants to architects ‚Äî who is curious about SAP Joule and wants to understand how it works. You're in the right place!

Disclaimer: This blog is based on publicly available information as of 24th July 2025, along with my personal interpretation. Sources of all referenced information, where available, are quoted in the REFERENCE section of this blog.

Topics covered in this blog are:

Welcome to the world of SAP Joule! Let's decode it into chunks! 

"How can I help you? 

Talk to me naturally. For example, 'What are my task for today?"

 

This is how Joule greets you in first place!

Joule ‚Äî a name derived from the unit of energy ‚Äî is here to energize our business processes, save valuable time, and simplify even the most tedious tasks resulting in greater efficiency and a noticeable uplift in the quality of our work.

SECTION 1: Understanding key terminologies and concepts:

Let‚Äôs cover some basic artificial intelligence terms before diving deeper into Joule for better understanding.

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that mimics human reasoning and behavior, enabling machines to make decisions on their own. By processing large volumes of data, AI can understand speech, identify patterns and trends, solve problems proactively, and forecast future outcomes.

  • GenAI also known as generative AI is a model where it can create new content which can either be text, image, audio and video based on the existing content that it already has.

  • LLM (Large language Model) is the specific model (like GPT, PaLM, LLaMA) that powers the text generation part of GenAI. It is a type of artificial intelligence model that is trained to understand and generate human-like language. It's designed to read, summarize, translate, predict, or generate text based on the input it receives. Eg, When we ask ChatGPT a question, it's an LLM that's interpreting our text and generating a relevant, natural-sounding response.

  • AI copilot is a virtual assistant that helps business application users complete tasks more easily through a conversational interface. It uses generative AI to understand requests, take actions, and offer insights from business data. AI Copilots use LLMs to understand natural language and assist users in real time.The answer that is provided to the user is limited to training data against LLMs. "Large" refers to the massive amount of data and the billions of parameters the model is trained on.

  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): In SAP world, customer specific data cannot be used to train the LLMs. And hence we need a better way to retrieve the desired outcomes without breaching the customer's data privacy. This is where RAG comes into picture. It is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). This is done through Document Grounding. As a part of preparation of RAG, it provided with SAP and customer specific documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are then chunked into smaller parts and are then embedded into dense, continuous vectors‚Äîknown as embeddings‚Äîwhich represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query. This information is passed to the LLM as prompts during runtime rather than getting it trained. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data. Rather, they get Grounded against customer specific data. 

  • HANA Vector Database enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords.

    Image source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uiv29xYlXvQ

  • For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. For instance, when a user asks about their company's paternity leave policy, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.

SECTION 2: What is SAP Joule and what are its use cases in the SAP world

SAP Joule is an AI copilot from SAP. Powered by SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), it serves as a virtual assistant that leverages generative AI to understand and respond to user requests within SAP systems.

Before diving deeper, Let's understand some of the use cases of SAP Joule. Below are some of the end-user prompts that can be sent to Joule, where it responds appropriately using natural language processing. These examples are sourced from SAP's official Joule product pages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html#agility-for-all

Why Joule?

Joule is SAP domain-specific and is integrated with SAP‚Äôs suite of products, ensuring seamless interaction and data exchange across the SAP portfolio. It is also a responsible AI solution, with a strong emphasis on industry-specific regulations and standards. As a result, Joule is a more Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible AI copilot for SAP.

As specified earlier, the LLMs in Joule are not actually trained to respond to SAP user queries. Instead, Joule use document grounding through RAGe (Retrieval-Augmented Generation for enterprise) for unstructured data, and the SAP Knowledge Graph for structured data, enabling it to provide more comprehensive responses by referencing business documents from both SAP and third-party repositories , while LLMs are used to add natural language rather than the actual context in the response that is sent to user by Joule. That is, Grounding uses a customer‚Äôs own knowledge sources (e.g., travel policies, enablement content, service manuals, FAQs, etc.) to supplement the capabilities of Large language models (LLMs). This gives Joule a unique understanding of SAP data and processes, allowing it to respond more reliably than any other AI copilot.

Joule is seamlessly integrated into various SAP cloud solutions to help users work more efficiently across different business functions, such as:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition

  • SAP SuccessFactors

  • SAP Ariba

  • SAP Sales Cloud

  • SAP Customer Experience solutions

  • SAP Concur

  • SAP ABAP Cloud

However, it is worth noting that Joule is not available for on-premise solutions.

Thus the main advantages of SAP Joule include:

  • Enhanced decision-making

  • Accelerated end-to-end business processes

  • Personalized UI with inherited user authorizations

  • Advanced analytics

  • Contextual awareness

  • Ability to meet diverse business needs

Business application supported by SAP Joule:

SAP Joule runs on the AI Foundation of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and supports a wide range of business application such as Finance, Procurement, Supply Chain, Human Resources, Sales and Services, Marketing and E-Commerce, Development, and Consulting.  Apart from some of the use cases described before, a detailed list of business use cases are available through URL => https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/use-cases.html

Joule's interaction pattern:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

Joule's interaction pattern can vary from:

  1. Informational: The Joule provides answers to factual questions (e.g. "What are the key rules for a team outing?")

  2. Navigational: The Joule guides users through a multi-step process or an internal journey, like approving a request or changing organizational data. (e.g. ‚ÄúWhere in the app do I send a promotion request?‚Äù)

  3. Transactional: The Joule engages in task completion workflows, e.g. reviewing and updating position details (job title, department, cost center), then confirming by saying ‚ÄúDone‚Äù. It also supports user edits and next steps before finalizing. (e.g. ‚ÄúUpdate the position title to Sustainability Supply Chain Consultant ‚Äî ready to submit?‚Äù)

  4. Analytical: The Joule offers data insights, metrics, and visual analytics, such as attrition trends vs. hiring rates charted by quarter. It helps users interpret numbers and trends. (e.g.‚ÄúWhat was our quarterly attrition rate in 2024?‚Äù)

SECTION 3: Joule architecture

Image source: Joule learning journey 

Joule architecture consists of key components which work together to respond to a user's question.

  1. Scenario Catalog: The Scenario Catalog holds information about all the available scenarios, functions, and skills in SAP cloud applications. In helps to distinguish between different user questions and guides Joule to understand the request and connect it to the right action or system or workflow. This acts like a blueprint that maps user queries to the appropriate actions, destinations, or logic within SAP systems. For example, if a user query is "Retrieves the current leave balance for a given employee", then this gets mapped as below:
    1. Scenario: 'Get_Employee_Leave_Balance'
    2. Business application : Human Resource
    3. 'leave balance': Employee ID, leave Type and Date Range.
  2. Knowledge Catalog: This contains SAP-knowledge as well as the customer-owned knowledge. It is a collection of documents and content sources (often unstructured or semi-structured) that are made available to Joule for question-answering using RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) techniques. It supports Joule in answering open-ended, natural language questions that aren‚Äôt directly tied to structured data or APIs. For example, it can have a company's HR policies (e.g., leave, travel, benefits), Finance guidelines (e.g., expense reimbursement rules) and so on. These documents are chunked and vectorized using embeddings in HANA vector database as specified earlier. When a user asks a related question, Joule retrieves relevant chunks and sends them to the LLM to generate a grounded answer.
  3. User Context: This helps joule to contextualize a user's question. This includes information about the SAP cloud applications the user is currently using, along with any additional SAP applications the customer has licensed and activated for use with Joule. Joule also recognizes the user‚Äôs roles and permissions, ensuring they can access only the information or perform the actions they are authorized to within the SAP cloud environment. Additionally, Joule takes into account the user‚Äôs chat history and context to provide most relevant and accurate responses to user queries. To put in other words, a user will be able to view or perform any tasks only if they are authorized to do so based on their existing authorization. 
  4. Document Grounding: Large Language Models (LLMs) are generally capable of understanding prompts and generating human-like responses. However, they often lack the context and specificity needed for business scenarios. To address this, Joule uses a technique called document grounding. This allows Joule to generate more accurate and relevant responses by referencing business documents stored in SAP and third-party repositories. As part of document grounding, customers can upload their own content (such as HR policies, travel policies, service manuals, etc.). When an end user asks a question, Joule searches these documents for relevant information and returns a concise, natural-language response, including the source references. This ensures the answers are grounded in the customer's own structured and unstructured data, making them more trustworthy and context-aware.
  5.  Grounding: This is the process of combining generative LLMs with advanced information retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy and relevance of responses‚Äîwithout the need to train or fine-tune the model on company-specific data. It leverages a customer‚Äôs internal knowledge sources (e.g., policies, FAQs, training material) to supplement the LLM‚Äôs existing knowledge. This improves the model‚Äôs reliability and ensures that responses reflect the customer‚Äôs unique business context.
  6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). As part of the RAG, Document Grounding is performed. In this step, RAG is provided with relevant documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are chunked into smaller parts and then embedded into dense, continuous vectors‚Äîknown as embeddings‚Äîwhich represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query.
  7.  HANA Vector Database: It enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords. For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. When a user asks about their leave balance, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.
  8.  Knowledge Graph: This graph is a semantic network that connects entities (like customers, products, orders, employees, etc.) and defines how they are related. This helps Joule go beyond keyword matching or document lookup. It actually lets Joule "understand" business context and structure.  Joule uses the graph to understand how different entities are linked (e.g., ‚ÄúEmployee X belongs to Department Y‚Äù or ‚ÄúInvoice A is tied to Purchase Order B‚Äù). With this, Joule disambiguate questions and provide more accurate answers.  It also enables logical inferences, like ‚ÄúShow me all open invoices for suppliers in Germany‚Äù, ‚ÄúList products related to a delayed shipment‚Äù etc. Even if the data is spread across multiple systems, the graph can link them together efficiently.

 

 

Image sources: Knowledge Graph or Vector Database‚Ä¶ Which is Better? and  GraphRAG: The Marriage of Knowledge Graphs and RAG: Emil Eifrem

NOTE: While RAG brings in document-based context and vector search finds the right text chunks, the Knowledge Graph brings in structure and relationship-based logic. Eg: RAG may find a document about a purchase policy, but the Knowledge Graph helps determine which department owns that policy and who can approve it.

Does LLM gets trained with SAP's data?

When SAP‚Äôs AI assistant Joule interacts with a Large Language Model (LLM), it doesn‚Äôt send data for storage or training. Instead, it shares information only briefly, as part of a prompt during runtime. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time, but it doesn‚Äôt remember or learn from what it receives. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data.

Joule's orchestration layer:

Image source: Examining how to onboard and extend Joule | AI105

Steps involved within Joule for processing user query:

  1. User submits query in natural language via Joule client in SAP cloud apps
  2. The prompt is sent to the Dialogue Management system, which manages the conversation flow and understands the user's intent.
  3. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) service forms a semantic vector search query based on the user input.
  4. This query is executed against a Vector Database where document embeddings are stored. The relevant document extracts are retrieved. These embeddings were created earlier from company-specific or SAP documents using document grounding
  5. The retrieved document snippets are passed along with the original prompt to a Large Language Model. The LLM uses the relevant extracts to ground its response (ensuring the response is based on actual documents, not hallucinations).
  6. The LLM generates a natural-language answer, grounded in the retrieved documents.
  7. The final answer is displayed to the user with source links and supporting documents attached.->Example: A link to a company travel policy PDF is shown under ‚ÄúSource Document‚Äù.

For more information, refer to Provisioning and Implementing Joule learning journey

SECTION 4: Joule packages and pricing: Base and premium

Joules comes in 2 different packages for consumption:

  1. Joule Base (No additional cost involved)
  2. Joule Premium

A. SAP Joule Base package: 

Joule Base package is available as supplement to all eligible SAP cloud subscriptions at no additional cost. As a prerequisite customer must have an active subscription to a supported SAP cloud product (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors). 

Current entitlements:

  1. Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities: To accelerate ABAP development with Joule
  2. Joule with SAP Fieldglass solutions: Enhance efficiencies across hiring processes with AI
  3. Joule with SAP LeanIX: Search and navigate to the right information through natural language queries.
  4. Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Streamline the informational, navigational, and transactional tasks.
  5. Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Streamline the informational, navigational, and transactional tasks.

Features:

  1. Provides access to a base set of Joule‚Äôs AI functions.
  2. Supports navigation, information retrieval, and basic task assistance within SAP cloud solutions.
  3. Unlimited usage under a flat fee model.

Joule is a central service and hence customer must choose the SAP BTP global account to attach Joule to in case of base package.  For more information on this regard, please refer to links below.

  • AI Catalog - Joule Base
  • SAP Joule Base Entitlement

B. SAP Joule Premium package: 

Joule Premium enhances the Joule Base with domain-specific and agentic AI features. It is available as a paid add-on through AI Units.

Premium Packages by Business applications(as on date 25th July 25):

  1. Joule Premium for financial management: Delivers deep financial insights and smart summarizations tailored for finance users. It brings in agent-driven capabilities that cover both transactional and analytical needs ‚Äî helping finance teams make better, faster decisions.
  2. Joule Premium for spend management: With features like Category Segmentation and Statement of Work (SOW) Description Generation, Joule Premium supports procurement and finance functions in improving efficiency and streamlining sourcing processes.
  3. Joule Premium for supply chain management: Enhances supply chain visibility with intelligent tools such as Equipment Insights and ESG Report Generation ‚Äî boosting transparency and operational awareness across logistics and asset-heavy processes.
  4.  Joule Premium for human capital management: HR teams can benefit from AI-Assisted Writing, Interview Feedback Insights, and other intelligent capabilities that help improve talent processes, communications, and candidate engagement.
  5. Joule Premium for customer experience: Designed to enhance customer engagement, Joule Premium in CX includes innovative features like Image Generation and Lead Booster to drive personalized interactions and improved conversions.
  6. SAP Joule for Consultants: SAP Joule empowers consultants with expert-level AI guidance, helping them accelerate SAP cloud deployments and ensure higher implementation quality and productivity.
  7. Joule for Developers: Joule acts as a real-time AI assistant for SAP developers, offering on-the-fly explanations of development objects, quick answers to dev-related queries, and seamless learning support.

Costing involved with Premium packages: AI Units

SAP Joules premium packages can be bought from the AI Catalog of Discovery center. URL:https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-catalog 

These are priced based on AI Units, which serve as a virtual currency that can be used across all SAP cloud products and lines of business through a shared AI Unit pool. AI Units are calculated based on predefined business metrics (e.g., transactions, pages, users, expenses), with each metric having its own conversion rate (e.g., 1 transaction = X AI Units). 

Purchasing premium licenses typically includes a fixed number of Joule messages per year (e.g., RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Premium includes approximately 2,500 messages). A single message refers to one user ask and the corresponding Joule response. Any usage beyond the included quota will consume additional AI Units.SAP provides an AI Unit Estimator Tool to help estimate AI Unit requirements based on selected capabilities and transaction volume. A quote can be requested directly through the estimator.

SECTION 5: Joule functionalities that is targeted at technology consultants

Two of the Joule premium that can help technology consultants are Joule for Consultants and Joule for developers.

A. Joule for Consultants:

SAP Joule for Consultants is a conversational AI solution that speeds up SAP cloud transformations by providing expert guidance drawn from SAP‚Äôs most extensive and carefully curated knowledge base.

Key uses:

  1. It is designed to reduce substantial amount of search time.

B. Joule for Developers: 

Joule for developers is part of SAP's Build portfolio. The primary objective of SAP Build is to enable citizen developers (business or end users) to build applications, processes, and business websites through visual drag-and-drop elements. It also helps professional developers accelerate development by generating data models, services, UI components, sample data, and business logic using Joule prompts.

NOTE: Joule with SAP Build is available as part of trial account or free tier. Upcoming SAP build details will have links to exercises that can be tried out with SAP BTP trial account.

Key components of SAP Build are:

  1. SAP Build Apps: SAP Build Apps helps both business users and developers quickly create and customize applications using low-code, AI assistance, and reusable modules‚Äîensuring fast, collaborative development across SAP and non-SAP systems.

  2. SAP Build Code: SAP Build Code is a powerful generative AI‚Äìbased code development environment for professional developers, offering end-to-end support for Java and JavaScript, AI-assisted coding with Joule, and a streamlined experience for collaborative SAP development across both expert and citizen developers. It provides a turnkey environment for coding, testing, integrations, and application lifecycle management.
  3. SAP Build Process Automation: SAP Build Process Automation lets both business users and developers automate workflows without coding, using drag-and-drop tools, AI, and pre-built content‚Äîboosting productivity, enabling collaboration, and running securely on SAP Business Technology Platform.
  4. SAP Build Work Zone: SAP Build Work Zone is a user-friendly platform that brings together apps, tools, and content in one place to help employees work smarter and stay informed by building digital workspaces & sites.

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that‚Äôs all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP‚Äôs commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.
